Fig 8 Photochemical synthesis of highly efficient Pt/TiO2 catalyst for thermal CO2 reduction to CO Zhanglong Guo Writing – original draft Supervision a ⁎ Li Wang Data curation a Jiacheng Zhang Investigation a Hongmei Zhou Methodology a Jianli Yang Data curation a Xin Xiao Supervision Methodology b a Key Laboratory of General Chemistry of the National Ethnic Affairs Commission, School of Chemistry and Environment, Southwest Minzu University, Chengdu 610041, PR China Key Laboratory of General Chemistry of the National Ethnic Affairs Commission School of Chemistry and Environment Southwest Minzu University Chengdu 610041 PR China aKey Laboratory of General Chemistry of the National Ethnic Affairs Commission, School of Chemistry and Environment, Southwest Minzu University, Chengdu 610041, PR China b College of Carbon Neutrality Future Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, PR China College of Carbon Neutrality Future Technology Sichuan University Chengdu 610065 PR China bCollege of Carbon Neutrality Future Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Supported platinum (Pt) catalysts are crucial for thermal CO2 reduction, yet traditional preparation methods often yield low catalytic activity. This study addresses this challenge by developing a photochemical deposition method to synthesize highly efficient Pt/TiO2 catalysts (Pt/TiO2-L) using only water as the solvent. The Pt/TiO2-L catalyst exhibited significantly higher CO2 conversion rates as 65 % at 600 °C and operational stability compared to traditionally prepared catalysts. TEM result revealed uniform dispersion of small Pt nanoparticles (around 1 nm) on the TiO2 support. XPS analysis showed a higher Pt surface content in Pt/TiO2-L, resulting in more active sites for CO2 reduction. In-situ CO-DRIFTS confirmed enhanced CO adsorption on Pt/TiO2-L due to its higher surface Pt content. This work demonstrates that the photochemical route is an effective and simple method for synthesizing efficient Pt/TiO2 catalysts for thermal CO2 reduction, offering promising prospects for industrial application in green chemistry. Graphical abstract Highly efficient Pt/TiO2-L catalyst with uniform dispersion of Pt nanoparticles (around 1 nm size) were synthesized via photochemical synthesis for CO2 thermal reduction. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photochemical route Enhanced catalytic performance Smaller particle size Thermal CO2 reduction Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The global imperative to mitigate climate change has led to a surge in research on the conversion of CO2, thus it's necessary to convert the potent greenhouse gas of CO2 into useful chemicals and fuels [1–3]. The thermal catalytic reduction of CO2 stands out as a promising approach to produce energy-rich products such as CH4 and CO under atmospheric pressure reaction conditions which can serve as building blocks for a range of industrial applications [4–7]. The development of efficient catalysts is the key to the CO2 thermal reduction process. Transition metal catalysts are the most common catalysts on the thermal catalytic reduction of CO2, particularly platinum (Pt), which has garnered significant attention due to its high catalytic performance [8]. Solís-García et al. [9] synthesized supported Pt catalysts by the wet impregnation method and the catalytic performance of these catalysts were enhanced through Rh incorporation for carbon dioxide thermal reduction. Fu et al. [10] developed a method to stabilize Pt SACs on the reduced TiO2 through using amine-molecule to assist in-situ anchoring Pt SACs during the preparation and showed a higher catalytic performance and stability for carbon dioxide thermal reduction to carbon monoxide. Huang et al. [11] compared the catalytic performances over pure and the supported Pt/CeO2 catalysts and found that Pt/CeO2 catalyst showed an enhanced activity performance at a lower temperature and CO2 conversion achieved at 6.7 % at 300 °C because of the significant increase in the number of Ce3+ sites on the surface of catalyst with the addition of Pt. From the analysis above, it is evident that the design of Pt-based catalysts with tailored properties is crucial for optimizing the reaction conditions and achieving high conversion rates and product selectivity. However, the Pt-based catalysts with the traditional preparation methods and monometallic often exhibit relatively low catalytic activity, which could not meet the practical industrial applications [12–16]. Thus, there is a strong need to develop a novel and easy approach to synthesize highly efficient Pt catalysts for carbon dioxide thermal reduction. High dispersed Pt catalysts could be prepared by the photochemical method for photocatalytic reactions [17–19]. This technique draws inspiration from the photochemical deposition of nanoparticles onto semiconductors, which is a well-established approach to enhance the photocatalytic performance of materials [19–24]. The process of photochemical deposition involves using light energy to induce chemical reactions and form the highly dispersed catalysts [25–27]. This method is attractive for its easy, safe, and environmentally friendly that could produce metal nanoparticles quickly without needing hazardous reagents or complex equipment [28–31]. However, photochemical deposition is primarily utilized in photocatalytic reactions, its application in thermal catalysis is not as extensive [32–35]. In this attribution, a series of Pt/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized by impregnation and photochemical deposition method and their catalytic performances were conducted out in CO2 thermal reduction. Besides, many characterization technologies, such as HAADF-STEM, XPS and in-situ CO-DRIFTS, were utilized to probe the relationship between structure and activity performance. As a result, Pt/TiO2-L catalyst prepared with photochemical deposition utilizing only water as a solvent presented a higher activity with a lower reaction temperature compared with that of impregnated Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-L-EG using water and ethylene glycol as a mixed solvent. Furthermore, this sample also presented superior operational stability after reaction for 50 h at 600 °C. This improved performance can be attributed to a suitable interaction between Pt and TiO2 support, smaller Pt particle distribution and higher Pt surface content. This study endeavors to offer valuable insights into designing highly efficient Pt/TiO2 catalysts for the thermal conversion of CO2 using a simple and straightforward approach. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The preparation process for the Pt/TiO2-L catalyst can be described as follows. First, weighting out 1 g of nano titanium dioxide (TiO2) and adding 10 mL of deionized water into the above solid, then adding 0.89 mL of the platinum precursor (H2PtCl6, 0.02878 mol/L) solution to the above mixer and determining the loading of platinum on the TiO2 support was 0.5 %. After that, placing the beaker on a magnetic stirrer at 380 r/min for 2 h to ensure a homogeneous distribution of the platinum precursor onto the TiO2 surface. Post stirring, the flask was exposed to UV light for 0.5 h with stirring and then transferred to a rotary evaporator with a water bath at 60 °C and initiate the evaporation process at 100 r/min to remove the solvent and concentrate the platinum-impregnated TiO2. After that, the flask was transferred to a vacuum oven and dried the material at 110 °C overnight. Following drying, the material was calcinated at 350 °C with a heating rate of 1 °C/min and maintained at this temperature for 4 h. For the preparation of Pt/TiO2-L-EG and Pt/TiO2 samples, the processes were similar to that of Pt/TiO2-L sample, except for 10 mL of deionized water being replaced with 8 mL deionized water and 2 mL ethylene glycol (EG) over Pt/TiO2-L-EG and without any UV light exposition process over Pt/TiO2. Besides, the samples with different Pt loadings of 0.1 %, 0.3 % and 1.0 % were also prepared and the preparation processes were similar to that of Pt/TiO2-L sample, except for the Pt loading, and the sample was named as 0.1 %Pt/TiO2-L, 0.3 %Pt/TiO2-L and 1 %Pt/TiO2-L, respectively. Furthermore, the samples with different ethylene glycol concentrations were prepared and the synthesis procedure was similar to that of Pt/TiO2-L-EG, except for the addition of ethylene glycol with 1 mL and 3 ml for Pt/TiO2-L-EG-1 and Pt/TiO2-L-EG-3. 2.2 Characterizations The loading of Pt on the sample was detected by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) using a Thermo ICAP PRO instrument. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to observe surface morphologies, composition, and microstructural detail of the prepared samples on Hitachi SU8010 field emission instrument. Low-temperature N2 adsorption/desorption measurements were obtained by using a Mircromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. Before conducting the analysis, the samples were degassed in vacuum at 200 °C for 24 h. Following the degassing, the textural properties were assessed using nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms at 77 K. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) theory was quantified employed to calculate the specific surface area, the total pore volume of the samples was calculated by evaluating the quantity of nitrogen adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.99, the average pore diameter was derived using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) approach, which is applied to the desorption branch of the isotherm. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the samples was carried out using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer from 10 degrees to 80 degrees for the variable 2θ, which utilizes a copper (Cu) target for the X-ray source, specifically the Kα radiation with a wavelength of 0.154 nm. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy was used to investigate the materials with unpaired electrons, the tested samples were reduced at 350 °C for 1 h with a H2 flow before the testing. The analysis of the samples was conducted utilizing X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on an Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer, which is operated with an aluminum (Al) Kα X-ray source, emitting photons at an energy level of 1486.8 eV. The XPS spectra generated were adjusted using the carbon 1 s (C1s) peak at a binding energy of 284.6 eV. High-resolution imaging and elemental distribution within the samples were investigated using a high angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) technique which was performed on a Thermo Scientific Talos F200X electron microscope with an accelerated voltage of 200 kV. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrographs of freshly reduced samples (350 °C, 1 h) were examined by Titan Themis ETEM G3 transmission electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 300 kV. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted by TP-5076 to identify and evaluate the reducibility. Typically, 50 mg sample was loaded into the reactor center and a continuous gaseous mixture of 5 % H2/N2 was delivered with a flow rate of 30 ml min−1. To remove surface absorbed or chemisorbed H2O and other contaminants, the sample underwent a pre-treatment process at a temperature of 200 °C for 1 h at N2 flow, then the baseline was kept stable in 5 % H2/N2 atmosphere at 50 °C. Once a stable baseline was achieved, the sample was then subjected to a temperature increase from 50 °C to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1, while the hydrogen consumption was continuously monitored using a thermal conductivity detector. In-situ CO-DRIFTS spectra were detected using a PerkinElmer Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectrophotometer by utilizing a reaction cell capable of admitting a variety of gases. Typically, approximately 30 mg of the sample was positioned in the sample holder and pre-treated at 200 °C for 1 h in a N2 flow (30 ml/min) to remove the air and water in the system. Following this, the sample was subjected to an in-situ reduction process at 300 °C for 1 h in the Drifts cell, maintained at ambient pressure and 5 %H2/Ar flow (30 ml/min). Following the pre-treatment, the samples were allowed to cool back to ambient temperature in a N2 environment and then exposed to 2 % CO/He gas for 0.5 h. Then the sample was purged with N2 to ensure the removal of any weakly physi-sorbed CO at room temperature, then the infrared spectra were recorded at ambient temperature with the PerkinElmer spectrometer, operating at a resolution of 4 cm-1 across the spectral range from 2300 to 1800 cm-1. For each experiment, the spectrum of the original solid catalyst before CO adsorption was used as background. CO2-TPD experiments were performed using a commercial TPD setup (BelCata II) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Typically, 0.1 g of the catalyst sample was placed in a quartz tube reactor and reduced under a 5 %H2/He flow (30 ml/min) at 350 °C for 1 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. Subsequently, the reactor was cooled down to 50 °C under He flow (30 ml/min). When the reactor temperature reached 50 °C, 10 %CO2/He gas was introduced, and the sample was exposed to this mixed gas for 60 min to allow adsorption. After that, the gas was switched to He (30 ml/min), once a stable baseline was achieved at this temperature, the sample was then heated to 800 °C in He flow (30 ml/min) with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and the desorption of CO2 was recorded as a function of temperature. 2.3 Catalytic testing The catalytic performances for CO2 thermal reduction were carried out from 200 °C to 600 °C at atmospheric pressure inside a fixed-bed reactor equipped with a quartz tube and the gas hour space velocity (GHSV) was regulated to 24,000 mL·g-1·h-1. Prior to the reaction testing, 100 mg of the calcined catalyst underwent in situ reduction at a temperature of 350 °C for 1 h in H2 flow controlled at 40 ml/min. Following the reduction process, the reactor was allowed to cool to 200 °C in N2 atmosphere and the mixed reaction gas of H2 and CO2 (H2: CO2 ratio equal to 4:1, 5 % N2 as the balance gas) was introduced into the reactor with a total flow rate of 40 ml/min. the outline gas was analyzed online by a gas chromatograph with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). CO2 conversion and CH4/CO selectivity were calculated as the previous reported work [36,37]. 3 Result and discussion The surface morphology and chemical element composition of these three TiO2 supported Pt samples were studied by SEM and EDS elemental mapping. Fig. 1 (a, c and e) shows that the presence of a plate-like structure with many pores between the structures spacing. In other words, it could be indicated that surface morphology did not be changed by the preparation method due to the mild conditions [38]. Furthermore, as presented in the EDS data in Fig. 1 (b, d and f), little Pt element were detected on these three samples due to the low Pt loading of 0.41 %, 0.41 % and 0.42 %, respectively, as confirmed by ICP-OES result. From the above EDS result, it can be concluded that Pt was successfully supported onto the surface of TiO2 materials. The texture properties of TiO2 based materials were characterised by N2 adsorption/desorption experiment. As shown in Fig. 2 a, all tested samples present typical IV-type isotherm with a H3-type hysteresis loop according to the IUPAC standard, which is usually tested for TiO2 based materials of plate-like structures with slit-shaped mesopores, this result confirmed pore size were mesoporous over the tested samples and helped the diffusion of gas during the reaction [39–41]. The average pore size was calculated as 30 nm based on the desorption curve by BJH equation (Fig. 2a interpolated picture). Besides, the surface area over the tested sample was around 27 m2/g, indicating the structure could not be changed with different preparation methods due to the mild condition. The redox performance of these three TiO2 supported Pt catalysts was carried out by H2-TPR experiment. As shown in Fig. 2b, three main reduction peaks were presented in all tested samples. According to the reported literatures, the reductive peaks located at around 120 °C mainly belonged to the peaks of reduction platinum oxide species, and the reductive peaks located at 350 and 550 °C were attributed to the reduction of TiO2 species [42,43]. As presented in the H2-TPR image, the reduction temperature of platinum oxide was 118 °C over the sample of Pt/TiO2-L which was lower than that of Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-L-EG samples, this result indicated that the interaction between Pt and TiO2 support was lower and the dispersion of platinum oxide species was higher over this sample, which would be expected to perform a higher CO2 conversion in the reaction. For Pt/TiO2-L-EG sample, the reduction temperature of platinum oxide species was highest at 129 °C with the strongest interaction between Pt and TiO2 due to the easier reduction of Pt to form particles and grow bigger on the surface of TiO2 with the addition of EG reducing solvent during the UV-irradiation, which would be confirmed by STEM result later. The phases present in TiO2 supported catalysis were revealed by the analysis of X-ray diffraction (XRD), and the corresponding results were shown in Fig. 2c. It can be observed from the XRD pattern that the crystalline constituent of these samples belonged to the rutile TiO2 phase with good crystallinity (JCPDS, no. 21–1276) [44]. No remarkable change was found in the crystalline phase over the different samples due to the mild preparation conditions [45]. Besides, the absence of the Pt diffraction peak over the tested samples in the XRD patterns might be attributed to the high dispersion or low loading of Pt nanoparticles. Considering there are unpaired electrons in the reduced samples, EPR spectra are carried out to test the presence of surface Ovs. As displayed in Fig. 2d, all samples showed an intense EPR signal at g = 2.003, which indicated the occurrence of Ovs species on the surface of samples due to the formation of Ti3+ species [46]. Furthermore, the EPR signal for surface Ovs in Pt/TiO2-L-EG is strongest among the tested samples, indicating that the generation amount of surface Ovs was highest which was attributed to the combined effects of UV-irradiation and EG reducing solvent. In addition, surface Ovs signal was higher in Pt/TiO2 sample compared to pure TiO2 because hydrogen molecular was more easily activated on metal Pt surfaces to form the Ti3+ species, and the signal was further enhanced in Pt/TiO2-L compared to Pt/TiO2 sample with the assistance of UV-irradiation because more electrons were produced on TiO2 during UV-irradiation which is beneficial to the reduction of surface oxygen in this sample. Based on the above results, it could be suggested that the surface structures, especially oxygen defects, were more beneficial to be formed by changing the preparation conditions. HAADF-STEM and TEM images of the reduced samples in Fig. 3 demonstrate the formation of Pt nano-particles on the surface of catalysts. Compared to the traditional catalyst of Pt/TiO2 in Fig. 3a, b which its mean particle size was calculated at 14.5 nm, the particle size in Fig. 3 g, h was bigger and measured at 16.0 nm in Pt/TiO2-L-EG due to the assistance of UV-irradiation and EG reducing solvent. For Pt/TiO2-L sample, Pt nano-particles were not easy to be observed from the STEM images in Fig. 3d Therefore, high resolution TEM were carried out on this sample and the result was shown in Fig. 3j, it showed high-density and small uniform size with around 1 nm (as shown in Fig. 3e) on the surface of Pt/TiO2-L, which were expected to show a better catalytic performance in carbon dioxide reduction than that of Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-L-EG catalysts based on the similar Pt loading on the catalysts detected by ICP-OES. Furthermore, the STEM-mapping images were carried out to analyze the element distrubution over the different catalysts. The obtained STEM-mapping results demonstrate that the Pt element on Pt/TiO2-L distributed more homogeneously with Ti and O elements than that of Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-L-EG catalysts, this distribution of Pt indicated the high dispersion of Pt on the Pt/TiO2-L sample which there were more activated sites to be involved in the reaction and showed a better catalytic performance. The catalytic performance is also related to the micro-structure of the catalysts, thus HRTEM were carried out to further investigate the micro-structure of the catalysts and the corresponding results were obtained in Fig. 4 . As shown in Fig. 4a, the latticle spacing of 0.329 nm were detected in this sample, which were attributed to the latticle spacing of TiO2 (110) [47]. For Pt/TiO2-L sample in Fig. 4b, nano-particles were observed clearly on the surface of this sample and the latticle spacing of 0.227 nm were detected in this sample, which belonged to the latticle spacing of Pt (111) [48,49]. Besides, the latticle spacing of 0.170 and 0.249 nm were also detected in this sample, which was attributed to the latticle spacing of TiO2 (211) and TiO2 (101), respectively [49,50]. This result demostrated that the exposed Pt enhanced the catalytic performance by providing a greater number of accessible active sites for reactant molecules. Fig. 4c and Fig. 4d showed the micro-structure of the Pt/TiO2-L-EG sample, it was seen that the latticle spacing of TiO2 (101) and TiO2 (110) were detected and the Pt particle surface was coverred by TiO2 species which would decrease the number of activated sites of Pt. Fig. 5 contains X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) data for a series of reduced samples, including Pt/TiO2, Pt/TiO2-L, and Pt/TiO2-L-EG, as well as a reference spectrum for TiO2. These spectra are indicative of the chemical states and electronic environments of the elements present in the samples after reduction treatment. The data is presented across four graphs, corresponding to different regions of the XPS spectrum. The full spectrum in Fig. 5a shows the presence of various elements in the samples, including oxygen (O 1 s), titanium (Ti 2p and Ti 2 s) and carbon (C 1 s). Fig. 5b displays the high-resolution spectrum of Ti 2p and the Ti 2p spectrum provides insights into the oxidation state and chemical environment of titanium. The Ti 2p3/2 peaks show a slight decrease in binding energy for the Pt/TiO2-L-EG sample compared to TiO2, which could suggest a change in the oxidation state of titanium or its interaction with platinum [51]. Fig. 5c shows the high-resolution spectrum of O 1 s, this spectrum is divided into two peaks, the peak located at 529.8 eV can be attributed to oxygen within the lattice of TiO2, while the peak at 531.6 eV is caused by surface oxygen in the metal oxide lattice [52,53]. As shown in Fig. 5c, the surface oxygen percentages of these samples to be 5.03 %, 5.83 %, 6.28 %, and 7.37 %, respectively. This result was consistent with that of EPR results in Fig. 2d. What's more, the binding energy in O 1 s peaks over the catalysts had a slight shift, suggesting minor changes in the oxygen environment due to the interaction with platinum and the reduction process. The Pt/TiO2-L-EG sample shows the lowest binding energy at 529.82 eV, which could indicate a more reduced oxygen state or a different chemical interaction with platinum, as discussed in the result of H2-TPR. The binding energy of O 1 s was highest and detected at 529.88 eV on Pt/TiO2-L sample than that of Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-L-EG samples as shown in Fig. 5c, this result suggested that there was more amount of electron transferred to the supported Pt metal on this sample, resulting in a higher electron density on Pt surface and catalytic performance over this sample. Furthermore, the chemical state of Pt was carried out over the samples and the corresponding result was shown in Fig. 5d. The samples show a significant peak in the 70–78 eV range, which is characteristic of platinum in a metallic or low oxidation state. The Pt/TiO2-L-EG and Pt/TiO2 samples also show peaks in this region, but with less intensity, suggesting a lower concentration or a different chemical state of platinum [48]. The XPS experiments have determined that the surface Pt content of the Pt/TiO2, Pt/TiO2-L and Pt/TiO2-L-EG catalysts are 0.12 %, 0.24 % and 0.08 %, respectively. The XPS results reveal differences in the surface Pt content and oxygen environment among the catalysts, a higher Pt surface content, as seen in the Pt/TiO2-L catalyst, provides more active sites for the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules. This increased number of active sites enhances to adsorb CO2 and H2 on the surface of catalyst, facilitating its subsequent reaction performance. Differences in the oxygen environment, main including the presence of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, affect the interaction with reactant molecules. Oxygen vacancies can serve as active sites for CO2 adsorption and activation, lowering the activation energy required for the reaction, the surface oxygen percentages over Pt/TiO2-L-EG catalyst were highest among the tested catalysts, while the Pt surface content was lower than that of Pt/TiO2-L catalyst, thus a higher catalytic performance was obtained on Pt/TiO2-L catalyst. In summary, the differences in surface Pt content and oxygen environment among the catalysts, as revealed by XPS, significantly impact the adsorption and activation of CO2 and H2. This result indicated that Pt/TiO2-L sample would be expected to show a higher catalytic performance due to the altered electronic structure and increased metallic platinum content. Fig. 6 a showcases in-situ CO-Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (CO-DRIFTS) data for three catalyst samples: Pt/TiO2, Pt/TiO2-L, and Pt/TiO2-L-EG. The wavenumber range presented is from 1800 to 2300 cm-1, which is typical for observing CO stretching vibrations. Adsorption of CO on both Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-L-EG catalysts only presented one IR band at about 2070 cm-1, this suggests a similar adsorption environment for CO on these two samples. In addition, the intensity of the adsorption peak on these two samples is lower, which could imply a lower adsorbed concentration of CO on the surface. When CO molecular was adsorbed and detected on the catalyst of Pt/TiO2-L, this sample exhibits two distinct peaks with higher intensity at 2084 cm-1 and 2058 cm-1, respectively, suggesting the adsorbed amount of the linear CO species higher on this catalyst due to the higher surface Pt content. These peaks are indicative of CO adsorption on different sites or in different chemical environments on the catalyst surface. The peak at 2084 cm-1 is typically associated with linearly adsorbed CO, while the peak at 2058 cm-1 could be due to bridge-bonded CO or CO adsorbed on smaller platinum particles as presented in Fig. 3 [54]. Fig. 6 b showed the CO2-TPD result of the three catalysts across the temperature range from 100 °C to 800 °C, two desorbed peaks were detected on these Pt/TiO2 catalysts, the lower peak located at around 90 °C might belong to the desorption of weak desorbed CO2. This desorbed temperature was much lower than the reaction, thus the result of this desorbed peak would not affect the catalytic performance. Pt/TiO2 catalyst exhibited a broad desorption peak cantered around 600 °C, indicating strong CO2 adsorption on this catalyst surface. For Pt/TiO2-L catalyst, a sharper peak was presented at a lower temperature (∼500 °C) compared to Pt/TiO2, suggesting easier CO2 adsorption and desorption at the reaction temperature range, which was attributed to the activation of CO2 molecular during the reaction. A broader peak with a maximum around 650 °C was displayed over Pt/TiO2-L-EG catalyst, indicating stronger CO2 adsorption and desorption than that of Pt/TiO2-L and Pt/TiO2 catalysts, resulting in a lowest CO2 conversion on this catalyst. The above CO2-TPD analysis further reveals that the Pt/TiO2-L catalyst exhibits favorable CO2 adsorption and desorption properties during the reaction range from 200 °C to 600 °C, which are crucial for its superior performance in the thermal catalytic reduction of CO2. The performance of each prepared catalyst in the CO2 reduction reaction was evaluated under conditions of a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 24,000 mL gcat −1 h−1 with a H2/CO2 molar ratio of 4.0, across a reaction temperature span from 200 °C to 600 °C. The CO2 conversion result within the reaction range from 200 °C to 600 °C is shown in Fig. 7 a. It can be found that the lowest carbon dioxide conversion was obtained on pure TiO2 without the assistance of Pt, this result confirmed the importance role of Pt during the catalytic reaction. CO2 conversion changed over the Pt supported catalysts with different preparation methods due to the different interfaces between Pt and TiO2. CO2 conversion of the tested catalyst increased with the temperature elevation in general and reached its peak at 600 °C. This phenomenon can be attributed to the exothermic nature of CO2 hydrogenation to CO, higher carbon dioxide conversion was easier to obtain at higher temperatures [55]. The CO2 conversion rates of pure TiO2 within the temperature range of 200–600 °C are lower than those of catalysts with supported Pt on TiO2, this result suggested the important role of supported metal during the reaction, which could enhance the activation of H2 molecular. Furthermore, the addition of Pt on TiO2 increased the CO2 conversion obviously and Pt/TiO2-L sample showed the highest performance within the reaction temperature and the highest CO2 conversion were calculated as 65 % at 600 °C. The significant increase in activity of Pt/TiO2 under high-temperature conditions was presented, this might be attributed to the enhanced Pt-TiO2 interfacial interaction. At elevated temperatures, the interaction between Pt and TiO2 becomes stronger, which might facilitate electron transfer and improve the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules such as CO2 and H2. This interfacial interaction can also lead to the formation of active sites that are more conducive to the catalytic reaction. Meanwhile, Fig. 7b showed the result of CO selectivity, and it could be found that the selectivity of CO was >85 % within the tested temperature range over the tested samples, indicating the generated product of CO facilitates was easy to be desorbed from the catalyst surface and helped to avoid the over-hydrogenation. Moreover, CO selectivity could be maintained at 100 % until the reaction temperature increased >350 °C on Pt/TiO2-L sample and obtained 85 % at the reaction temperature of 600 °C due to the high CO2 conversion obtained at high reaction temperatures. However, CO selectivity can always be kept close to 100 % over the remaining catalysts of TiO2, Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-L-EG. Considering the above result discussed, it could be proved that the catalyst of Pt/TiO2-L had an excellent catalytic performance. Fig. 7c presented the production rate on the samples at the reaction temperature of 400 °C, the results showed that only CO was produced on TiO2, Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-L-EG samples and the CO production rate was calculated as 14.27 μmol g-1 cat.s-1 on Pt/TiO2 which was higher than that of TiO2 (0.48 μmol g-1 cat.s-1) and Pt/TiO2-L-EG (7.42 μmol g-1 cat.s-1) [56]. However, the CO production rate was highest at 22.57 μmol g-1 cat.s-1 on Pt/TiO2-L sample despite of little CH4 producing on this sample. As presented in Fig. 7d, the activation energy on Pt/TiO2-L was calculated as 26.96 kJ/mol which was much lower than that of Pt/TiO2 (42.93 kJ/mol) and Pt/TiO2-L-EG (49.03 kJ/mol) catalysts. This result might be related to the Pt smaller particle size (Fig. 3) and higher Pt surface concentration (Fig. 5), resulting in a higher catalytic performance presented over Pt/TiO2-L catalyst in the reaction of carbon dioxide reduction. In addition to the high catalytic performance, the high stability is also one of the most important performances to develop the industrial catalyst, thus the stability was carried out over Pt/TiO2-L catalyst with the best catalytic performance in the thermal reduction of carbon dioxide on the long stream time for 50 h at 600 °C and the corresponding results were shown in Fig. 7e. As a result, the catalytic performance on Pt/TiO2-L catalyst showed 66 % CO2 conversion and 86 % CO selectivity during the whole process of carbon dioxide hydrogenation at the tested reaction condition for a long time testing over 50 h, the above result presented an outstanding catalytic stability on this catalyst because of the interaction between Pt and TiO2, which could help to anchor the activated metal Pt on the surface of catalyst, resulted in preventing the shift of Pt on the surface of catalyst during the harsh reaction condition, thus a high stability presented on this catalyst [57]. Fig. 8 a presents the CO2 conversion efficiency of Pt/TiO2-L catalysts with different Pt loadings as a function of temperature. The results show that all catalysts exhibit increasing CO2 conversion with temperature, when the temperature increases above 400 °C, significant differences in CO2 conversion efficiency emerge among the catalysts. The 0.5 %Pt/TiO2-L catalyst consistently shows the highest conversion rates, reaching approximately 65 % at 600 °C, followed by the 0.3 % and 1.0 % catalysts, the 0.1 %Pt/TiO2-L catalyst exhibits the lowest conversion efficiency across the entire temperature range. The 0.5 %Pt/TiO2-L catalyst demonstrates superior performance, suggesting that this Pt loading is optimal for CO2 conversion. This can be attributed to a balance between active site density and accessibility. Higher Pt loadings (1.0 %) may lead to particle agglomeration and reduced surface area, while lower loadings (0.1 %) may not provide sufficient active sites for efficient CO2 adsorption and activation. Furthermore, Fig. 8b presents the CO selectivity of Pt/TiO2-L catalysts with different Pt loadings as a function of temperature, the results show that all catalysts maintain high CO selectivity across the entire temperature range, with values consistently above 85 %, this indicates that the catalysts are highly selective for CO production. At lower temperatures (200–400 °C), the selectivity is slightly higher, ranging from 90 % to 100 %, suggesting efficient CO production under milder conditions. As the temperature increases above 400 °C, a slight decrease in selectivity is observed for the 0.5 % and 1 % Pt/TiO2-L catalysts, possibly due to the changes in the reaction pathway. However, the selectivity on all tested catalysts remains above 85 % even at 600 °C, indicating robust performance under varying thermal conditions. Fig. 8c presents the CO₂ conversion efficiency of Pt/TiO2-L-EG-1, Pt/TiO2-L-EG-2, and Pt/TiO2-L-EG-3 catalysts as a function of temperature. The results show that all catalysts exhibit increasing CO2 conversion with temperature, indicating that the reaction is thermally activated. At temperatures below 400 °C, the CO2 conversion for all catalysts remains relatively low, ranging from 0 % to approximately 20 %. This suggests that the reaction kinetics are limited at lower temperatures, possibly due to insufficient activation energy for CO2 adsorption and dissociation on the catalyst surface. The similar performance of the three catalysts in this temperature range indicates that structural differences have minimal impact on low-temperature activity. Above 400 °C, significant differences in CO2 conversion efficiency emerge among the catalysts. Pt/TiO2-L-EG-3 consistently shows the highest conversion rates, reaching approximately 50 % at 600 °C, followed by Pt/TiO2-L-EG-2 and Pt/TiO2-L-EG-1. This trend suggests that this catalyst prepared with a higher ethylene glycol concentration would affect the structural characteristics, enhance its catalytic performance at higher temperatures. Besides, the selectivity of CO on these catalysts were shown in Fig. 8d, the results show that all catalysts exhibit 100 % CO selectivity across the entire temperature range evaluated, this indicates that the catalysts are highly selective for CO production. 4 Conclusions Overall, highly stable dispersed Pt/TiO2 catalysts have been successfully synthesized through straightforward photochemical routes, and this catalyst presented a higher activity with a lower reaction temperature in the thermal catalytic reduction of CO2, comparing with that of Pt/TiO2 prepared by impregnation and Pt/TiO2-L-EG using water and ethylene glycol as a mixed solvent. In addition to the high CO2 conversion, this sample also showed superior operational stability at high reaction temperature. This enhanced performance was attributed to the Pt small particle size with uniform distribution and high Pt concentration on the surface. Based on the results in this contribution, it is believed that photochemical routes have a great potential application in thermal catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Supported platinum (Pt) catalysts are crucial for thermal CO2 reduction, yet traditional preparation methods often yield low catalytic activity. This study addresses this challenge by developing a photochemical deposition method to synthesize highly efficient Pt/TiO2 catalysts (Pt/TiO2-L) using only water as the solvent. The Pt/TiO2-L catalyst exhibited significantly higher CO2 conversion rates as 65 % at 600 °C and operational stability compared to traditionally prepared catalysts. TEM result revealed uniform dispersion of small Pt nanoparticles (around 1 nm) on the TiO2 support. XPS analysis showed a higher Pt surface content in Pt/TiO2-L, resulting in more active sites for CO2 reduction. In-situ CO-DRIFTS confirmed enhanced CO adsorption on Pt/TiO2-L due to its higher surface Pt content. This work demonstrates that the photochemical route is an effective and simple method for synthesizing efficient Pt/TiO2 catalysts for thermal CO2 reduction, offering promising prospects for industrial application in green chemistry.
